abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Service Reform
            Project (PSRP) for Tanzania are as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory, risk to the development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was highly satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was rated as satisfactory. Some of the
            lessons learned included: 1) the process and pattern of
            change in the PSRP1 indicates the critical importance of
            leadership at different levels of the Government. In
            retrospect, the design of the reform strategy of the PSRP1
            was a key factor in subsequent performance. The contextual
            factors were generally enabling. The relationships with the
            development partners (DPs) were largely supportive. But what
            integrated these elements and focused them on productive
            outcomes was the nature of Tanzanian leadership. 2) A key
            outcome of the PSRP1 was the capacity development of the
            President's Office, Public Service Management (PO-PSM),
            the main Government agency with a mandate to manage
            system-wide change and reform. One perspective on this
            process is to disaggregate this emerging capacity into four
            capabilities, all of which were essential for effective
            PO-PSM performance. These were the following: a) the
            capability to carry out technical, managerial and logistical
            tasks; b) the capability to adapt and change; c) the
            capability to engage and form relationships with other
            actors; and d) the capability to achieve greater coherence
            both internally and externally.
